text: here's a big old thistle anybody would recognize it I've been mob grazing if you will the horses in this area so they've grazed this right back the sheep were in here before then the horses some people do the horses first and then the sheep but my sheep are my prophet not the horses so in here you can see there and there the horses have eaten the flowers of the thistles so it cuts down on the seed population I'll come in and I'll chop this down as well so some of them they've left the seed heads is there it didn't quite get to the stage where they were tasty for the horses but a lot of the other ones you can see they chomped through all the thistle heads right here there's an old saying a chop in May you double the display chop and June you've cut too soon cut in July and you watch them die basically the horses you can see trimmed this thistle bloom and this one here but you can see a second one coming on so that's basically what they're talking about is doubling the display and there's more flower heads coming up in there despite the horse chop eating that one so these are some more here thistles that the horses ate blooms off of it was hey I was getting from a particular farmer was always full of thistle so I've spent years fighting thistles and when I came home these fields were nothing but thistles and rye grass so here you can see the horses haven't been in this section you can see the grass is higher and you can see the flower heads of the thistles forming and when the horses come in they will eat those so you can see the height of the grass there versus the height of the grass where the horses haven't been so the horses have been here and they're going in there now it is eaten back by the sheep but I'm getting instead of mowing it or topping it I'm getting the horses and you see they're fertilizing it as well and so I do the field and sections so that their manure is relatively evenly spread I'll now come in and Harrow these products that are now free of fencing so here you can see for manure piles but they're dispersed around the place they're not all in one location because I've done I think in this small section here you can see the horses up there so in this small section here where you can see the electric fence down that fence line here this side of the row of trees the other side of this dead oak tree and to there I think I've done three six nine ten twelve paddocks so they're now starting on their thirteenth paddock which is up here at the top and they have a line that electric fence up there there's a lane for them to go down to the water trough which is right there so you can see here is the product they're grazing and here is the new product sorry this is the paddock they're grazing now this is the next paddock they're gonna go into you can see there's electric fence and that's a third paddock so I'm dividing a strip into three and it spreads the manure because horses always have their favorite patch to go and in a big field and their favorite patch to eat and this way they have to everywhere and this is is what's really good for the soil health and I'll come in with the Harrow you can see they there's no particular location now where they it's everywhere which is great and I'll also come in and chop down those huge thistles now that I've changed where I get my hey I'm no longer I'm working on people who have diverse wards of hay and feeding my sheep that to resew more into my fields this field here the Rams you can see are right under that tree over there so they're sharing their free-ranging in the field but the horses are paddock grazing
